Award.AwardTitle: IRFP: Signal detection in noise in the grasshopper Chorthippus biguttulus
Award.AbstractNarration:
The International Research Fellowship Program enables U.S. scientists and engineers to conduct nine to twenty-four months of research abroad. The program's awards provide opportunities for joint research, and the use of unique or complementary facilities, expertise and experimental conditions abroad.

This award will support a twenty-four month research fellowship by Dr. Michael S. Reichert to work with Dr. Michael Greenfield at the Research Institute on Insect Biology in Tours, France.

Animal communication often takes place in noisy environments and noise imposes constraints on the important tasks of signal transmission, detection and localization. In addition, communication is often a multi-directional process: signals can be transmitted to multiple receivers and signalers may engage in reciprocal signaling interactions with one another. Despite this, few studies have examined the effects of noise on multi-directional signaling interactions in animals. This study examines the effects of noise on communication in a species that engages in acoustic duets involved in mate recognition and localization, the European grasshopper Chorthippus biguttulus. Both males and females of this species produce and respond to acoustic signals during these processes. By using the tools of signal detection theory and controlled experiments examining the responses to signals in noise of individual males and females, as well as duetting pairs, this study tests the prediction that noise has stronger impacts on multi-directional signaling, and examines the consequences of noise on natural communication interactions.

This study involves three specific projects. In the first, the signal detection abilities of males and females are compared by exposing individuals of both sexes to synthetic song models of the opposite sex in various levels of masking noise and measuring individual response thresholds. In the second, signal detection in noise is compared for unidirectional and duetting signal interactions, with the prediction that duetting interactions will suffer from greater levels of signal detection errors. In the third, assays of the response of females to mating signals under varying levels of noise are used to determine how signal attractiveness is affected by masking noise.

The benefits of this project include an increased understanding of the effects of noise on acoustic signal detection and recognition. The processing of sound in the brain of the study species is well-described. Therefore, this project generates new insights on how simple nervous systems deal with the challenges of signal perception in complex and noisy environments. This has broad implications that could lead to a better understanding of hearing in noise that applies to other systems, including humans. In addition to these benefits, this research will provide the PI with important opportunities to develop collaborations with major international research groups at the Research Institute on Insect Biology (Prof. Michael Greenfield) and at Humboldt University in Berlin, Germany (Prof. Bernhard Ronacher).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study examined the effects of noise on acoustic communication in a European grasshopper, Chorthippus biguttulus. Noise is an unavoidable challenge for communication, and studying how different animals overcome this challenge not only gives important insights into animal behavior and the evolution of communication systems, but also reveals a great deal about the mechanisms of hearing. Furthermore, as humans continue to encroach on natural habitats, noise made by human activities will become increasingly prevalent, and basic research into how animals maintain effective communication in noise will provide important background knowledge for conservation efforts. This grasshopper species was an especially suitable study system for several reasons: (1) It communicates acoustically in the context of mate selection and localization, and this signaling likely takes places in high levels of background noise arising from both other signaling grasshoppers and abiotic sources such as wind, (2) The communication system of this species is bidirectional: males and females engage in a duet by which the female selects attractive males based on their song characteristics, and then gives a song of her own which is used by the selected male to localize her. Because both individuals serve as signaler and receiver, but in different contexts, the effects of noise on different tasks and with different potential consequences can be studied, and (3) The mechanisms of hearing are well understood in this species and we could therefore test predictions based on the neurophysiology of hearing at the behavioral level. Few species for which the behavioral effects of noise have been studied are also so well-understood physiologically.

 

We made several notable findings in this project. First, we found that noise has effects on how male grasshoppers localize females. Surprisingly, the accuracy with which males turned in the direction of a simulated signaling female was only slightly affected by even high levels of noise. However, the likelihood of approaching a female in the first place was substantially impaired by noise. This suggests that different sound-processing pathways in the nervous system are differentially affected by noise, and that noise may impose costs on mate localization in the field. Second, we found that noise affected which males females were attracted to. We measured female responses to male songs that differed in the level of certain song characteristics, and repeated these measures in different background noise levels. Females’ preferences changed dramatically depending on the noise level. For some signal characteristics, females had strong preferences for specific levels of that characteristic in quiet conditions that were completely eliminated when there was loud background noise; for other signal characteristics the pattern was in the opposite direction. This result is important because it suggests that different males would be selected as mates in different background noise conditions, a process that could eventually lead to the formation of new species. Third, males’ abilities to determine the direction of a sound depended greatly on when in the song the directional cues were available. The beginning of a song seems to be especially important for certain types of cues, while the middle of the song is the most important for others. Because of echoes and reverberations in the environment, it will be common that directional cues vary over the course of a signal, and our results suggest a fundamental sensory bias in how these cues are processed. If this bias is general across animals, this will be a major advance in our understanding of how directional hearing works in complex environments.
